Today, I joined my colleagues in condemning the horrific assassination of Charlie Kirk.

Political violence has no place in this country. If someone can be attacked for holding views you disagree with, then someone can just as easily be attacked for holding views you share. 

I know how frightening these times are – each and every day members of Congress are faced with dangerous threats to their life, including myself. That’s why we must be united in condemning political violence, no matter our political beliefs.

I want to be clear: I did not agree with Charlie Kirk’s views. Too often, his engagement was neither civil nor respectful, and he supported ideas that are harmful and out of line with the values we should be building toward – especially when it comes to women, the Black community, and the LGBTQ community.

My vote reflects my condemnation of political violence, period.

For too long, bad trade deals have squeezed the middle class, manufacturing, and damaged our national security. I believe tariffs are an important tool to support American workers, and when used strategically to fight cheap steel from China, tariffs can be critical in protecting our domestic industry.

Now, China has retaliated, and the stock market is crashing. While people's savings plummet and they look for reassurance, the President is golfing. It's unacceptable.

Congress has a role to play here. I am ready to work with the President to negotiate stronger trade agreements that prioritize our workers, rather than strain our economy. It’s time for smarter, effective trade policies that benefit every American.
